content:
As an AI language model, I don't have personal preferences or opinions, but all of the landmarks in Uxbridge have their own unique significance and appeal. Here are some suggestions for landmarks to visit in Uxbridge, based on their historical significance:

- St Margaret's Church: This church, which dates back to the 14th century, is one of the oldest buildings in Uxbridge and has a rich history. It was once the site of a royal palace and has been the setting for many important events over the years.

- Hillingdon Court: This historic mansion was built in the 17th century and was once the home of the Earl of Arundel. It has been used for various purposes over the years, including as a school and a museum, and is currently being renovated.

- The Crown Inn: This coaching inn has been in operation since the 16th century and was once a popular stop for travelers on their way to London. It has been restored and is now a hotel and pub.

- The Battle of Uxbridge Monument: This monument commemorates the Battle of Uxbridge, which was fought during the English Civil War. It is located in the center of Uxbridge and is a popular spot for tourists and locals alike.

- The Colne Valley Park: This large park covers over 40 square miles and includes many historic sites, including the Uxbridge Canal and various old farmhouses and mills. It's a great place to explore the natural beauty and history of the area.
